title: true friend of the countries of Asia, Japan shall build lasting, heart-to-heart relations of mutual trust

Ohira Masayoshi offered a plan for Pacific Rim solidarity to “enable the Pacific region to become one regional society.” Furthermore, Ohira worked tirelessly as foreign minister in the cabinet of Tanaka Kakuei (1918-93) for the revival of Sino-Japanese diplomatic relations, and the “All-China Japanese Teacher-Training Institute
Opium War erupts
1842 Treaty of Nanjing: Qing dynasty opens five ports and cedes Hong Kong to Great Britain 1851 Taiping Rebellion begins
arrival of Commodore Perry in Japan; Crimean War breaks out 1854 Kanagawa Treaty (peace treaty between U.S
Shimoda Treaty (commercial treaty between Japan and Russia

1856 eruption of Arrow War in which Britain and France invade China Great Britain commences direct rule in India; Britain, France, the U.S,, and Russian conclude Treaty of Tianjin with the Qing; Japan and U.S. conclude treaty of amity and commerce; Aigun Treaty between Russia and China concluded
Treaty of Beijing concluded, ceding part of Kowloon peninsula to Britain and giving Russia possession of the Maritime Province

1864 squadron of British, French, American, and Dutch battleships fire on Shimonoseki 1868 Meiji Restoration 1871 seeking commerce, U.S. occupies Korean stronghold at Kanghwa Island; Sino-Japanese Friendship Treaty concluded 1874 Japanese military expedition to Taiwan
1875 treaty exchanging Sakhalin and the Kurile Islands; Unyo Incident at Kanghwa Island
Treaty of Friendship (Treaty of Kanghwa) between Japan and Korea concluded 1879 Japanese seizure of Ryukyu Islands 1882 Imo Incident (military mutiny) in Korea 294 Chronology
Kapsin Incident (coup d'état) in Korea; Sino-French War erupts; Russia and Korea establish diplomatic ties
Tianjin Treaty concluded: Qing relinquishes suzerainty over Vietnam, which become protectorate of France 1887 French Indochinese Union formed
Otsu Incident in which there is attempted assassination of Russian Crown Prince Nikolai Aleksandrovitch; Russia begins laying track for Trans-Siberian Railway
1894 rebellion of Tonghak Party in Korea; Sino-Japanese War commences
Treaty of Shimonoseki signed and China cedes Liaodong peninsula, Taiwan, and Penghu Islands to Japan; Tripartite Intervention and Liaodong peninsula restored to China
Russia leases Lushun and Dalian and acquires rights to build Chinese Eastern Railway (Harbin-Lashun-Dalian); Germany leases Jiaozhouwan; Great Britain leases Weihaiwei
U.S. announces Open Door policy for China; France leases Guangzhouwan
Boxer Rebellion erupts; Joint Expeditionary Forces led by Japan and Russia sent to suppress it
Beijing Protocol signed in which Qing agrees to pay huge indemnities to the powers and allow their armies residence in Beijing; Chinese Eastern Railway opened to traffic
Trans-Siberian Railway between Vladivostok and Khabarovsk opened to traffic; Chinese Eastern Railway between Harbin and Manzhouli opened to traffic; Anglo-Japanese Alliance concluded
Chinese Eastern Railway between Harbin and Lishun and

First Independence Movement (Korea); reorganization of the Guandong Governor-General’s office and the establishment of a Guandong Government and the (independent) Guandong Army; May Fourth Movement; China forces Mongolia to abandon autonomy 1920 League of Nations is launched
formation of the Guangdong military government; Chinese Communist Party founded in Shanghai

container-title: advocacy on behalf of China passes and Japanese interests regress
title: Sun Zhongshan (Sun Yat-sen) launches Northern Expedition; Zhang Zuolin announces independence of the Three Eastern Provinces (Manchuria); Washington Naval Limitations Treaty signed; Nine-Power Treaty concluded—U.S
First United Front between the Chinese Communists and Nationalists (Guomindang); declaration of independence by the People’s Republic of Mongolia
Sun Zhongshan and Jiang Jieshi (Chiang Kai-shek) commence Northern Expedition; May 30 Incident, an anti-imperialist movement of workers in Shanghai
Zhang Zuolin organizes military government in Beijing and becomes generalissimo

note: Mao Zedong and the Red Army commence struggle for armed, liberated areas
title: first Japanese dispatch of troops to Shandong; Far Eastern Conference convened in Japan (decision reached on the severance of Manchuria-Mongolia and to support the Guomindang); Jiang Jieshi’s coup d'état and the end of the First United Front

Guomindang government recommences Northern Expedition; second Shandong expedition by Japan; murder of Zhang Zuolin; Zhang Xueliang unites forces with Nationalist government; Ishiwara Kanji becomes staff officer with Guandong Army 1929 beginning of Great Depression
May 30 uprising in Jiandao led by Korean Communists resident in Jiandao
Liutiaohu Incident; occupation of Fengtian and Chichihar by the Guandong Army
Guandong Army occupies Harbin; State-Founding Proclamation of Manzhouguo; Lytton Commission comes to Manchuria; Japan-Manzhouguo Protocol
Guandong Army occupies Shanhaiguan and invades Rehe Province; Japan secedes from the League of Nations; Tanggu Truce concluded

note: formerly, Chinese Eastern Railway
title: Japan, Manzhouguo, and Soviet Union conclude transfer of the North Manchurian Railway
Japan and Germany conclude Anti-Comintern Pact; Xi'an Incident occurs in which Jiang Jieshi imprisoned by Zhang Xueliang and Zhou Enlai’s reasoning prevails
Marco Polo Bridge Incident; Second United Front; Nationalist government moves its capital to Chongqing
first Konoe statement abrogating diplomatic relations with China; second Konoe statement announcing the New Order in East Asia

note: concluded
